newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy bad loans equalled 11.2 pct of loans in Sept.
newsitem.headline: Italy bad loans equalled 11.2 pct of loans in Sept.

text.p: Italian banks' gross bad loans rose 14.3 percent in September year-on-year to reach 119.10 trillion lire, equal to 11.2 percent of total loans, the Italian banking association ABI said.
ABI said in its monthly report that growth in bad loans had slowed from August when they rose 15.2 percent year-on-year and from 15.4 percent in July.
"First estimates show that the slowdown is likely to have continued in October," ABI said.
But the ratio of bad loans to all loans continued to rise after 11.14 percent in August and 10.89 percent in July.

Turning to bank loan data for December, ABI said loans by banks holding short-term deposits, accounting for all high street banks, rose by just 2.35 percent year-on-year in the month to 877.0 trillion lire, against an increase of 2.66 percent in November and 3.66 percent in October.
Lire loans rose 3.91 percent in December year-on-year to 802.0 trillion lire after a 4.45 percent rise in November and a 5.88 percent increase in October.
But foreign currency loans fell 11.8 percent to 75.0 trillion lire after a 12.7 drop in November and a 14.53 percent decline in October.

High street bank deposits rose just 3.43 percent year-on-year in December to 915.0 trillion lire against an increase of 4.98 percent in November and 4.29 percent in October. --Milan newsroom +392 66129589
